title: Bankers stung by the extent of their unpopularity
text:
Searing criticism

As one of the country's most highly regarded bankers noted: "I'm not sure the authorities are going to want to share their thinking to any great extent."

Meanwhile, bankers pointed out that the chairmen and chief executives of the big four banks already hold "very private and very discreet" discussions with officials from the Reserve Bank, Treasury and regulators, where they can voice concerns that ultra-low rates are crimping their profitability.

Still there's no denying the country's top bankers have been deeply stung by the searing criticism they received following their decision last week not to pass on the full quarter percentage point rate in the official cash rate.

Prime Minister Scott Morrison made sure the big banks felt the government's fury, accusing the banks of "basically profiteering".

And the Reserve Bank last week scotched bankers' claims that ultra-low rates are eroding their profitability noting our banks remain among the most profitable in the world.

In its October Financial Stability Review, the Reserve Bank appeared to endorse the Coalition's criticism that the banks are prioritising profits over customer.

Advertisement

Banks fume over pay

It said that recent declines in banks' net interest margins reflect the cost of repaying customers who were previously overcharged interest, as well as increasing price competition in the home loan market and a switch by customers to lower-margin loans.

In contrast, the banks are adamant that their margins are being squeezed because, as rates move lower, a growing proportion of their deposits are paying zero interest, or close to it, and so cannot be pushed any lower.

Their tussle with Canberra over their failure to pass on rate cuts in full isn't the only issue troubling the major banks.

Senior bankers are also fuming over the latest comments by Australian Prudential Regulation Authority boss Wayne Byres on the sensitive issue of banker remuneration.

Under APRA's new rules, no more than 50 per cent of the bonuses paid to senior bank executives can be linked to financial performance. That will force boards to put more weight on non-financial measures - such as customer satisfaction, customer complaints, and employee engagement - in determining bonuses.

But although Byers conceded that APRA's proposal had been widely and strongly criticised, he said the onus was on the critics to come up with an alternative proposal "that isn't just the status quo because outcomes from the status quo have been found unacceptable".

Bankers have been left flabbergasted by Byres' argument. Not only does it demonstrate the regulator's contempt for their views, but it also indicates that APRA felt under such strong pressure to make changes that it would prefer to push ahead with a deeply flawed policy rather than to leave things as they are.

"If senior bankers are going to be measured by the level of customer satisfaction and customer complaints, then the easiest way to address that problem is simply to stop lending to people who are most likely to be problem customers," said one highly regarded bank director.

"This is already happening, but Byres doesn't seem too interested in addressing that issue."
description: It's symptomatic of the poor standing of the country's major lenders that the regulator is pushing ahead with its widely condemned bonus proposal.
